metadata.title: Ru nanoparticles stabilized by poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) grafted onto silica: Very active and stable catalysts for hydrogenation of aromatics
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 7482 S1381-1169(09)00115-0 10.1016/j.molcata.2009.03.002 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 The synthesis procedure to prepare Ru/silica-PVP. Fig. 1 (a) N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and (b) pore size distribution curves of activated silica (A) and the silica with grafted PVP (B). Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of activated silica (A), silica-MPS (B) and silica-PVP (C). Fig. 3 TGA curves of activated silica, PVP, silica-PVP and Ru/silica-PVP in air. Fig. 4 TEM images of Ru/silica-PVP at different magnifications (a, b). The inset of (b) displays the HRTEM image of a single Ru nanocrystal in the catalyst Ru/silica-PVP. Fig. 5 (a) Ru 3d signals recorded for the Ru/silica-PVP and (b) XPS survey spectrum of as-prepared Ru/silica-PVP. Fig. 6 Effect of reaction temperature on TOF. Reaction conditions: benzene (0.258g), Ru/silica-PVP (10.0mg), 4MPa H2, conversion>99.5%. Fig. 7 Effect of pressure of H2 on TOF. Reaction conditions: benzene (0.515g), Ru/silica-PVP (10.0mg), 383K, conversion>99.5%. Fig. 8 Conversions of benzene vs reaction time. Reaction conditions: benzene (0.515g), Ru/silica-PVP (10.0mg), 4MPa H2, 383K. Table 1 Hydrogenation of aromatics under different conditions. A=silica-PVP, B=Ru/silica-PVP, C=Ru/silica-[TMG], D=Ru/silica-[DAM]. Ru nanoparticles stabilized by poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) grafted onto silica: Very active and stable catalysts for hydrogenation of aromatics Xiaosi Zhou Tianbin Wu Baoji Hu Tao Jiang Buxing Han ⁎ Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 10 62562821. Graphical abstract PVP is grafted on the surface of silica chemically. Ru nanocatalysts supported on the PVP-modified silica exhibit very high catalytic activity for solvent-free hydrogenation of aromatics. In addition, the catalysts are very stable, can be easily separated from the products and reused, and the support is widely available and cheap. Poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP) was successfully grafted onto silica by a two-step method developed in this work. The Ru nanoparticles/silica composites were fabricated using the PVP-modified silica. Nitrogen adsorption, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques were used to characterize the nanocomposites. The results showed that Ru nanoparticles with the size of about 2–5nm that possessed high crystallinity were immobilized on the silica grafted by PVP. The hydrogenation of aromatics was studied using the nanocomposites as the catalyst. It was found that the catalyst was very active for the reactions, and was very stable due to the stabilizer PVP grafted on the surface of the silica. Keywords Ruthenium Poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) Grafting Hydrogenation Aromatics 1 Introduction Application of transition-metal nanoparticles in catalysis has attracted much attention [1–3]. Thermodynamically, naked nanoparticles tend to aggregate to form larger particles, resulting in decrease in catalytic activity and selectivity. To overcome this problem, different methods to stabilize metal nanoparticles have been developed for effective catalysis, and different kinds of stabilizers, such as ionic liquids [4–8], dendrimers [9–11], polymers [12–14] and ligands [15], have been used in liquid media or on solid supports. In many cases, the compatibility of nanocatalysts and stabilizers is crucial for high efficiency of the catalytic systems. Generally, the catalytic activity is low if the interaction between the stabilizer and nanocatalyst is too strong, whereas it fails to stabilize the nanoparticles if the interaction is too weak. Poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP) has shown to be excellent stabilizer for metal nanocatalysts [16–18]. Tsukuda and co-workers [19] synthesized monodisperse gold nanoclusters stabilized by PVP for effective aerobic oxidation of benzylic alcohols. Hwang et al. [20] prepared PVP-modified graphite carbon nanofibers that were used as catalyst supports for PtRu catalysts in direct methanol fuel cells, and satisfactory results were achieved. Kou and co-workers [21] reported that Rh nanoparticles stabilized by PVP-contained ionic copolymers were long lifetime nanocatalysts for benzene hydrogenation in ionic liquid 1-n-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]), and PVP encapsulated noble metal nanoparticles exhibited highly catalytic activity for hydrogenation of cellobiose and carbon monoxide in water [22,23]. These indicate that PVP is an excellent stabilizer in liquid solvents. Synthesis of cheap, highly active and stable heterogeneous catalysts is of great importance for chemical industry. The ordinary silica is preferred support from both economic and process points of views. PVP stabilized metal nanocatalysts on silica can be expected to be excellent catalysts for many chemical reactions. To anchor PVP on silica chemically is a key to fabricate the stable catalysts. Herein, we develop a route to graft PVP onto silica, followed by preparation of silica-supported Ru nanoparticle catalysts. The catalysts were then used for the hydrogenation of aromatics, which are important industrial transformations [24,25]. It was demonstrated that the catalysts showed very high catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of aromatics although the reactions were carried out in the heterogeneous catalytic system, and the catalysts were very stable and could be easily reused after easy separation. In addition, the catalysts were relatively cheap because commercially available and cheap silica of 200–300 mesh was used. We believe that the method can also be used to support some other noble metal nanocatalysts on silica stably. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone (NVP) was purchased from Acros. Silica (200–300 mesh) was provided by Yantai Chemical Industry Institute. 3-Methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS) was supplied by Beijing Shenda Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Other chemicals (A.R. grade) were purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagent Company and used without further purification. 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidinium tetrafluoroborate ([TMG][BF4]) and 1-(N,N-dimethylaminoethyl)-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([DAM][BF4]) were prepared according to reported procedures [26,27]. 2.2 Characterization The BET surface area was determined by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer, and the pore size distributions were derived from the adsorption branches of the isotherms. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a PERKIN-ELMER7 Series Thermal Analysis System with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in the air with a flow rate of 20mLmin−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2011 electron microscope operated at 200kV, and the samples for TEM measurement were prepared by placing drops of sample on copper grids coated with lacey carbon film. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was conducted on an VG Scientific ESCALab220i-XL spectrometer operated at 15kV and 20mA at a pressure of about 3×10−9 mbar using Al Kα as the exciting source (hν =1486.6eV). The content of Ru in the catalyst was obtained from inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, VISTA-MPS, VARIAN Corp. USA). The composition of the support (silica-PVP) was determined with a Flash EA 1112 analyzer. 2.3 Catalyst preparation 2.3.1 Preparation of MPS-functionalized silica Silica was activated by heating at 150°C for 12h. 3-Methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS) (2.5g), activated silica (10g) and anhydrous toluene (250mL) were added into a 500mL three-necked flask with a magnetic stirrer and a condenser under an argon atmosphere. After 24h of reflux, the MPS-treated silica was filtered off and extracted with dry toluene for 24h to remove the unreacted MPS using a Soxhlet apparatus. Then, the obtained MPS-functionalized silica was dried at 70 °C under vacuum overnight. 2.3.2 Preparation of Silica-PVP A mixture of MPS-functionalized silica (1.0g), NVP (5.0g), AIBN (0.1g) and methanol (25mL) was first degassed by three freezing/thaw cycles and then heated in an oil bath at 60 °C with stirring. After 24h, the reaction mixture was diluted with methanol. Then, the diluted mixture was filtered and washed with copious amount of methanol. The residually dissociative poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP) was removed by using Soxhlet extraction with 300mL methanol for 24h. The final product (silica-PVP) was dried under vacuum at 60°C overnight. 2.3.3 Preparation of Ru/silica-PVP The catalyst precursor was synthesized by the method of “incipient wetness”. 16.0mg of RuCl3·3H2O was dissolved in 1.6mL of twice-distilled water. The supported catalyst precursor was obtained by addition of the above solution to 0.784g of silica-PVP under stirring, and dried under vacuum at 70°C overnight. In a typical reduction, the dried catalyst precursor (0.6g) was dispersed in 3.0mL of twice-distilled water. Then, NaBH4 (18.6mg) in 1.5mL of twice-distilled water was added dropwise under vigorous stirring. After about 2.5h, the heterogeneous mixture was filtered and washed three times with water, and the obtained catalyst was dried under vacuum at 70°C overnight. 2.3.4 Preparation of Ru/silica-[TMG][BF4] and Ru/silica-[DAM][BF4] 0.0544g of [TMG][BF4] was mixed with 1.5mL of water. 0.600g of activated silica was then mixed with the ILs aqueous solution, followed by drying in a blast oven to obtain the support silica-[TMG][BF4]. The content of nitrogen element in the silica-[TMG][BF4] was the same as that in silica-PVP. Then, the support (0.3430g) was impregnated with an aqueous solution containing 7.0mg of RuCl3·3H2O and the mixture was dried in a blast oven. Finally, the catalyst precursor was reduced by H2 at 220°C for 3h under flowing hydrogen. Ru/silica-DAM was prepared using the same procedure as preparing Ru/silica-TMG. 2.4 Hydrogenation reaction The reaction was performed in a 6mL stainless-steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical hydrogenation, 10mg of catalyst and 0.515g of benzene were added into the reactor and the air was replaced by H2. The reactor was heated to desired temperature, and H2 was added to reach the desired pressure. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled quickly in an ice-water bath and the hydrogen was released slowly. After the catalyst was centrifuged from the suspension, the upper liquid phase was analyzed by GC (Agilent 6820) equipped with a flame-ionized detector. 3 Results and discussion Scheme 1 shows schematically the synthesis of Ru nanocatalysts stabilized by PVP grafted onto silica support (Ru/silica-PVP). The 3-methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS) was first attached on the surface of silica by reaction of –OH groups on the silica and the (CH3O)3–Si– groups in the MPS to obtain silica-MPS. Then, polymerization of N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone (NVP) and the MPS on the silica was conducted using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as the initiator. Ru3+ ions were then introduced into the PVP layer on the silica surface, and they were subsequently reduced by NaBH4 to obtain light dark catalyst Ru/silica-PVP. 3.1 N2 adsorption–desorption study Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of silica and silica-PVP (PVP grafted onto the silica). The smaller BET surface area (259m2 g−1), pore volume (0.60cm3 g−1) and pore size (about 9.3nm) of silica-PVP compared with those of the corresponding silica (289m2 g−1, 0.96cm3 g−1 and 13.3nm, respectively) resulted from grafting of PVP on the surface of silica. 3.2 FT-IR characterization Fig. 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of the silica, silica-MPS and silica-PVP. The band at 1632cm−1 is attributed to the bending vibration of water molecules adsorbed on the surface of silica [28]. After the silica was modified by MPS, peaks at 1634, 1703 and 2959cm−1 are assigned to CC, CO and C–H stretching vibrations of MPS, respectively, indicating the bonding of MPS on the surface of silica [29]. After polymerization, the peak at 1664cm−1 attributed to CO stretching vibration of PVP and the peak at 1703cm−1 corresponding to CO stretching vibration of MPS can be observed, while the peak at 1634cm−1 assigned to CC double bond of MPS has disappeared, indicating that MPS unites were incorporated into the copolymer chain by free radical polymerization [30]. 3.3 TGA characterization Fig. 3 shows the TGA results of silica, PVP, silica-PVP, and Ru/silica-PVP. A significant weight loss can be observed in the TGA curve of silica-PVP from 290 to 700°C, which can be attributed to the weight loss of PVP. The weight loss of Ru/silica-PVP occurred mainly in the temperature range of 290–370°C, which was lower than that for silica-PVP due to catalytic combustion of Ru oxides formed in air at high temperature [31]. The content of Ru in Ru/silica-PVP determined by ICP analysis was 0.33wt%. 3.4 TEM characterization TEM study revealed that Ru nanoparticles with the size of about 2–5nm were dispersed in Ru/silica-PVP, as shown in Fig. 4 . To determine the crystallinity of the Ru in the catalysts, the Ru/silica-PVP embedded in poly(methyl methacrylate) was cut with an ultramicrotome to obtain ultrathin sections of the catalyst, which were examined by high resolution TEM (HRTEM). The inset of Fig. 4b shows a HRTEM image of a single Ru nanoparticle taken in a section of the catalyst. The average lattice spacing in the Ru nanoparticle is 0.23nm corresponding to the (100) Ru crystal plane [32]. XPS study. Fig. 5 shows the XPS (VG Scientific ESCALab220i-XL) spectra of the Ru/silica-PVP. Cl 2p is barely detectable in the catalyst, indicating that RuCl3 has been reduced by NaBH4 aqueous solution [23,33]. The intense O 1s and C 1s peaks and the weak N 1s peak reveals that PVP has been grafted onto silica. The peak at 284.6eV is interpreted as the combination of C–C structure of PVP and a carbon contaminant. And the peaks with higher binding energies located at 285.8 and 287.0eV can be attributed to C–N and CO structures of PVP, respectively. Two peaks at 283.9eV (Ru 3d3/2) and 279.8eV (Ru 3d5/2) prove the existence of Ru nanoparticles in the catalyst. However, the Ru nanoparticles are easily oxidized in open air and its oxide also has excellent catalytic activity in hydrogenation of arenes, so the presence of a little RuO2 cannot be excluded on the Ru nanoparticles surfaces. Furthermore, RuO2 could be further reduced under the hydrogenation conditions to give Ru nanoparticles during the reaction [34–38]. In addition, the binding energy of 287.0eV confirms the presence of CO, which is consistent with the FT-IR results 3.5 Hydrogenation reaction We first studied the hydrogenation of benzene at various conditions using different catalysts, and the results are listed in Table 1 . The TOF of the reaction increased as the temperature increases (Fig. 6 ). Similarly, the TOF also increased with the increase of the pressure of H2 due to the increase of reactant concentration in the catalytic system (Fig. 7 ). However, the TOF was small when the pressure of hydrogen was too low (Table 1, entry 2). Moreover, the conversion of benzene increased smoothly with the reaction time which is shown in Fig. 8 . The turnover frequency (TOF) of Ru/silica-PVP (entry 3) was about 1.9 times of the very active Ru/C-silica catalyst under the same temperature and pressure of H2 reported recently in the literature [31]. After the reaction, the catalyst could be easily separated by centrifugation. The recovered catalyst was rinsed with ether three times. After drying, the catalyst could be reused for next hydrogenation reaction and no decrease in catalytic activity was noticed after reused five times (entries 4–8). The support (silica-PVP) was also used as catalyst for hydrogenation of benzene (entry 1), and no product was detected after 2h, indicating that the catalytic activity results from Ru nanoparticles. To determine whether the catalyst was heterogeneous or homogeneous, the reaction was stopped and the catalyst was removed from the reaction system by centrifugation before the hydrogenation of benzene was finished. Then, the liquid phase was loaded into the reactor and hydrogen was recharged. The reaction did not occur in two hours as confirmed by the GC analysis. This shows that the reaction proceeded in a heterogeneous catalytic system. Ionic liquids (ILs) can also be used as stabilizers for noble metal nanoparticles [4–8]. In this work, two ILs 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidinium tetrafluoroborate ([TMG][BF4]) and 1-(N,N-dimethylaminoethyl)-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([DAM][BF4]) were also used to stabilize Ru nanoparticles on the silica, and the catalysts are denoted as Ru/silica-[TMG] and Ru/silica-[DAM], respectively. The content of the N element in the Ru/silica-[TMG] and Ru/silica-[DAM] was controlled to be the same as that in the Ru/silica-PVP (the mass content of nitrogen in silica-PVP determined by elemental analysis was 1.72%). Hydrogen was used as the reducing agent because both ILs will be washed away in the washing process if NaBH4 was used. Ru/silica-[TMG] and Ru/silica-[DAM] were obtained by reducing silica-TMG-Ru3+ and silica-DAM-Ru3+ through H2 at 220°C for 3h. In addition, both of two ILs were stable under this temperature [4,27]. It can be seen that the TOF of Ru/silica-PVP was much higher than that of the catalysts stabilized by the ionic liquids. The main reason may be that the interaction between the ionic liquids and the Ru particles is too strong, leading to the decrease of catalytic activity. The catalyst Ru/silica-PVP was also used to catalyze the hydrogenation of toluene and p-xylene. The catalyst is also very active for the two substrates (entries 11–17, 18). The decrease in activity was not noticeable after the catalyst was reused five times for hydrogenation of toluene (entries 12–16). In a word, Ru nanocatalysts stabilized by PVP grafted onto silica have very high catalytic activity and excellent stability for the hydrogenation reactions. One of the reasons is that the interaction between the stabilizer and nanocatalysts is moderate. Another possible reason is that the surface of the Ru nanoparticles may be exposed partially because the content of the PVP in the catalyst is low. The detailed mechanism of high catalytic activity is very interesting and requires further study. 4 Conclusion We developed a route to graft PVP on the surface of silica chemically, and Ru nanocatalysts supported on the PVP-modified silica can be easily prepared. The catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity for solvent-free hydrogenation of aromatics. Moreover, the catalysts have some other advantages, such as very stable and easily reused, easy separation from the products, and the support is widely available and cheap. We believe that the catalysts have great potential for industrial application due to the unusual advantages. coredata.dc:description: Poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP) was successfully grafted onto silica by a two-step method developed in this work. The Ru nanoparticles/silica composites were fabricated using the PVP-modified silica. Nitrogen adsorption, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques were used to characterize the nanocomposites. The results showed that Ru nanoparticles with the size of about 2–5nm that possessed high crystallinity were immobilized on the silica grafted by PVP. The hydrogenation of aromatics was studied using the nanocomposites as the catalyst. It was found that the catalyst was very active for the reactions, and was very stable due to the stabilizer PVP grafted on the surface of the silica.
coredata.dc:title: Ru nanoparticles stabilized by poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) grafted onto silica: Very active and stable catalysts for hydrogenation of aromatics
